questions.text: A lady on OCP presents with white vaginal discharge that presents with no itching or foul smell. It stains her underwear yellow in color and on examination of the discharge normal lactobacilli were present and pH was acidic. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
NORMAL PHYSIOLOGICAL DISCHARGE:

  • vaginal squamous cells and cervical columnar cells in fluid medium
  • clear to cloudy colour
  • nonhomogenous
  • highly viscous or sticky
  • no itching, vaginal burning, or malodour
  • increase at the time of ovulation, during pregnancy, following menstruation
  • normal endogenous microflora(lactobacilli)
  • pH was acidic

Reference: Modern Gynecology by Ajit Virkud, Chapter 5, Page no. 43

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman came to opd with a complaint of dysmenorrhoea, deep pelvic pain and infertility. Examination reveals a tender adnexal mass with fixed retroverted uterus with nodularity in POD. Best investigation to establish the diagnosis of this condition is:
questions.solution:
Diagnostic laparoscopy is the gold standard for diagnosing endometriosis.

Typical lesion: Powder burn/Gunshot lesions (black, dark brown, or bluish cysts with old hemorrhage surrounded by variable degree of fibrosis)

Other non-typical findings could be:

  • Red implants
  • Serous or clear vesicles
  • White plaques/scarring
  • Yellowish brown discoloration of peritoneum
  • Sub ovarian adhesions
  • Histological confirmation of laparoscopic impression is essential for diagnosis of endometriosis.

Reference: Shaw 15th/ed p 470; Novak 15th/ed p 516.

questions.text: A 12-year-old young girl presents in the casualty with acute pain in the lower abdomen. She has history of cyclical pain for the last 5 months and she has not attained her menarche yet. On Per rectal examination, bulge is felt along the entire length of vagina. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
A young girl who has not attained menarche but has a history of cyclical pain for last 6 months, presenting to casualty with acute abdomen and on examination a bulge along the entire length of vagina (associated with hematocolpos, hematometra) clearly point towards Imperforate hymen as the diagnosis. Another characteristic feature is bulging bluish membrane which increases on coughing, straining.

Reference: Shaw 15th/ed, Page no. 96-97.

questions.text: A 34-year-old mother of two children has been suffering from amenorrhea for the last 12 month. She has a history of failure of lactation following second delivery but remained asymptomatic thereafter. Serum FSH, estrogen levels are low. Skull X-ray shows empty sella. Diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Empty Sella:

  • Congenital incompleteness of the sellar diaphragm.
  • Secondary to surgery/radiotherapy or infarction of pituitary tumor.
  • Secondary to infarction and necrosis of pituitary gland.

Now from the given causes:

  • either pituitary tumor or Sheehan's syndrome can cause an empty sella on X-ray.
  • Pituitary tumours (micro/macroadenoma) are prolactin secreting tumors and hence, cause galactorrhea (not lactational failure) with amenorrhea and are ruled out.

Sheehan's syndrome:

  • It is the syndrome which results from ischemic necrosis of most of the anterior pituitary due to spasm in its arterioles occurring at the time of severe hemorrhage or shock, complicating childbirth.

Reference: Williams Gynae 1st/ed, pg no: 374.

choices.text: No need of removal (wait and watch)

questions.text: A 28-year-old P1L1 had Cu T inserted 2 years back, on examination Cu T threads are not seen. USG shows Cu T partly in the abdominal cavity. Method of removal is:
questions.solution:
Copper can cause inflammatory reactions and can cause intestinal obstruction. Therefore, never wait and watch.

When Cu T is embedded within uterine cavity, hysteroscopic removal is the method of choice. It is preferred over IUD hook. Hysteroscopy cannot visualize the Cu T that is in the abdominal cavity.

So when IUCD enters the abdominal cavity (partly or completely), laparoscopy is the preferred modality for retrieval. Sometimes due to dense adhesions around the Cu T, a laparotomy may be required to remove it.

Reference: SK Chaudhary 7th/ed p 114

questions.text: In a case of incontinence of urine, dye filled into the urinary bladder does not stain the pad in the vagina, yet the pad is soaked with clear urine. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
In the question: In the methylene blue swab test, dye filled in the bladder does not stain the pad in vagina but it is soaked with clear urine which means it is a uretero vaginal fistula.

Reference: Dutta Gynae 6th/ed p 420; Shaw 15th/ed p 186

questions.text: Fourteen weeks pregnancy with third degree prolapse. Best management will be:
questions.solution:
Other indications of Ring pessary:

  • In puerperium – to facilitate involution.
  • Patient unfit or unwilling for surgery.
  • Women who have undergone at least one previous attempt at surgical intervention without relief.
  • Diagnostic - It may be placed diagnostically to identify which women are at risk for urinary incontinence after prolapse correction surgery.

Note: Pessaries are of two varieties:

  • Supportive pessary eg-Ring pessary
  • Space occupying pessary eg-Gellhorn pessary

Reference: Dutta Obs 6th/ed p 312-3; Shaw 15th/ed p 337-8; Williams Gynae 1st/ed p 545-7

questions.text: A patient treated for infertility with clomiphene citrate presents with sudden onset of abdominal pain and dis tension with ascites, the probable cause is:
questions.solution:
Side effects of clomiphene:

  • Multiple pregnancy (6-8%) < 10%
  • Ovarian cysts
  • Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (<1%)

Anti Estrogenic side effects

  • Hot Flashes, osteoporosis
  • Long Term use-ovarian malignancy

Note: No congenital malformation seen

  • Most common effects are hot flashes and ovarian cyst formation.

Reference: Jeffcoate 7th/ed p 652

questions.text: A 29-year-old primigravida patient with and uncomplicated pregnancy undergoes spontaneous labour during second stage of labour she was given right mediolateral episiotomy to enlarge vaginal opening after delivery obstetrician notices extension of episiotomy laceration in mucosa with intact anal sphincter, degree of perineal tear in this patient will be classified as:
questions.solution:
Classification of Obstetric Anal Sphincter Injury (RCOG-2007)

  • First degree: Injury to perineal skin only
  • Second degree: Injury to perineum involving perineal body (muscles) but not involving the anal sphincter- episiotomy
  • Third degree: Injury to perineum, involving the anal sphincter complex (both external and internal)

3a: <50% of EAS thickness torn

3b: >50% of EAS thickness torn

3c: Both EAS and IAS torn

  • Fourth degree: Injury to perineum involving the anal sphincter complex (EAS and IAS) and anal epithelium

Reference: Shaw's textbook of gynecology, 16th edition, chapter 1(figure 1.12, A)

questions.text: A 32-year-old G4P3, previous 3 vaginal delivery comes to emergency at 38 weeks of gestation with an episode of bleeding. Bleeding was not associated with pain. On examination her pulse is 80bpm, BP 110/70 mmHg. Uterus is relaxed, FHS 130 bpm regular and there was no bleeding at the time. Immediate ultrasound was done for localization of placenta. Placenta is seen covering the internal OS on TVS. Which of the following is best for her?
questions.solution:
The best option for her is (B): Caesarean section.

In this case, the ultrasound shows that the placenta is covering the internal os, indicating placenta previa.

In placenta previa-mode pf delivery- cesarean section

Timing of delivery -in uncomplicated cases by 37 week.

Expectant management, induction of labor, or artificial rupture of membranes are not appropriate in this scenario. Expectant management is not advised for full term pregnancy, when the patient is in labour and has severe bleeding.

Reference: William's obstetrics 26th edition, chapter 43

questions.text: All are done in management of shoulder dystocia except:
questions.solution:
Shoulder Dystocia:

The term shoulder dystocia is used to define a wide range of difficulties encountered in the delivery of the shoulders (A head to body delivery time exceeding 60 secs defines shoulder dystocia).

First line measures:

  • Immediately after recognition of shoulder dystocia extra help should be called, in the form of midwifery assistance, an obstetrician, a paediatric resuscitation team and an anaesthetist.
  • Maternal pushing should be discouraged, as this may lead to further impaction of the shoulder, thereby exacerbating the situation.
  • Liberal episiotomy should be given to provide more space posteriorly.
  • Fundal pressure should not be employed. As it is associated with an unacceptably high neonatal complication rate and may result in uterine rupture.
  • Moderate suprapubic pressure can be applied by the assistant.
  • McRoberts' manoeuvre is the single most effective intervention and should be the first manoeuvre to be performed. The McRoberts manoeuvre is flexion and abduction of the maternal hips, positioning the maternal thighs on her abdomen.

Second line measures: They should be done only, if first line measures fail:

  • Wood's manoeuvre: It is progressively rotating the posterior shoulder by 180°. So that the impacted anterior shoulder is released.

Third line measures-They should be done only, if second line measures fail:

  • Cleidotomy: Fracturing the clavicle bone of the fetus
  • Symphysiotomy: Dividing the pubic symphysis of the mother
  • Zavanelli manoeuvre: Replacing the head of the baby back into the pelvis followed by cesarean section.

Note: Some other maneuvers earlier used were Hibbard and Rubin method.

Reference: Dutta Obs. 7/e, p 406

choices.text: Admit the patient, start antihypertensives and continue pregnancy till term.
Admit the patient, start antihypertensives, MgSO4 and terminate the pregnancy
Admit oral antihypertensives and follow up in out-patient department

questions.text: A female of 36 weeks gestation presents with hypertension, blurring of vision and headache. Her blood pressure reading was 180/120 mm Hg and 174/110 mm Hg after 20 minutes. How will you manage the patient?
questions.solution:
In the question, patient is presenting with Headache, Blurring of vision, B/P = 180/120 mm of Hg (later 174/110 mm of Hg) i.e. she is a case of severe pregnancy induced hypertension.

First step in the management of this case would be to prevent seizures i.e. give MgSO4.

Her B/P should be controlled with antihypertensive and since pregnancy is >34 weeks, therefore terminate pregnancy (which is the definitive management).

Reference: Fernando Arias Practical Guide to High Risk Pregnancy and Delivery 3/e, pg 417, 420, 424

choices.text: Patient may continue breastfeeding at her own risk
Patient should breast feed her baby only if her INR is <2.5
Patient can breast feed her baby after the 6 weeks course of warfarin is over
Warfarin is not a contraindication for lactation

questions.text: Sarita, a 30-year-old woman develops a deep vein thrombosis in her left calf on the fourth postoperative day following a caesarean section done for foetal distress. The patient is started on heparin and is scheduled to begin a 6 weeks course of warfarin therapy. The patient is a devoted mother who wants to breastfeed her baby. What is the advice that can be given to the patient?
questions.solution:
• Warfarin is contraindicated in the first trimester of pregnancy as it can lead to Conradi syndrome comprising of microcephaly, optic atrophy, nasal hypoplasia, and chondrodysplasia punctate. It can also lead to IUGR, abortions and IUD.
  • But warfarin is absolutely safe during lactation as an extremely minute quantity of it is excreted in the breast milk.

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 7th Edition, Page Number-146.

choices.text: Immediate clamping, cutting and ligation of cord

questions.text: Which is not included in active management of III stage of Labour?
questions.solution:
Active management of the third stage of labour includes:

  1. Administration of a uterotonic soon after birth (best is oxytocin)
  2. Delayed cord damping
  3. Delivery of placenta by controlled cord traction
  4. Uterine massage if tone of uterus is decreased

Now this leaves us with no doubt that 'Early cord clamping' should not be included in active management of labour. Reason - why early cord clamping is being discouraged is because if cord is clamped immediately the cord blood present in it(80-100 ml) will go waste whereas, if delayed cord clamping is done, the cord blood goes to the newborn and their are less chances of anemia, intraventricular hemorrhage and late onset sepsis especially in preterm infants.

Reference: Dutta Obs. 7/e, pg 141, 142; Sheila Balakrishnan 1/e, pg 149; Management of Labour by Arulkumaran; Penna & Rao 2/e, p 196, Recent Advances in Obs and Gynae Vol 24 edited by William Dunlop, pg 93

questions.text: Indication of caesarean section in case of intrauterine fetal death includes:
questions.solution:
Place of the caesarean section in a case with IUD is limited. Previous cesarean sections (two or more), major degree placenta previa and transverse lie are the rare conditions.

Reference: D C Dutta's textbook of obstetrics 8th edition, chapter 22

questions.text: A woman with eclampsia is started on magnesium sulphate. What is the first sign of MgSO4 toxicity?
questions.solution:
Monitoring for magnesium toxicity

  • Urine output should be at least 30 ml/hrQ
  • Deep tendon reflexes(Patellar reflex) should be presentQ
  • Respiration rate should be more than 14/min.Q
  • Pulse oximetry should be ≥ 96%

Remember

Repeat injection are given only if:

  • Knee jerks are present
  • Urine output > 30 ml/hour
  • Respiratory rate ≥ 14/min

If MgSO4 toxicity: Give Calcium Gluconate.

Knee Jerk lost >10meq/l(first sign).

Resp depression >12meq/l.

Resp paralysis >15meq/l.

Cardiac arrest .25meq/l.

Reference: William's Obstetrics, 26th edition, Chapter 41, Clinical management of preeclampsia syndrome, Page no. 1861

choices.text: Iron and folic acid tablets - 3 tablets OD
Iron and folic acid 2 tablets OD + IV sucrose
IV sucrose for non compliance with oral tablets

questions.text: Under the Anemia Mukt Bharat Program, mild to moderate anemia is treated using:
questions.solution:
As per anaemia mukth bharat program , mild to moderate anaemia is treated with oral iron twice daily, if patient is non-compliant  to medication, Parentral iron is given .

Reference: Dutta's textbook of obstetrics edition, 9th edition, chapter 19, Page no. 260

questions.text: Identify the uterine anomaly shown in the HSG film?
questions.solution:
HSG: Hysterosalpingogram(HSG) is mainly preferred in uterine anomalies but it cannot distinguish between a septate and bicornuate uterus. This is because in order to distinguish between the two, uterine fundus should be visible.


In Bicornuate uterus the 2 halves of mullerian duct do not fuse and there is defect in fusion of fundus as well.

In septate uterus a septum passes down from the uterine fundus. The fundus is normal in appearance.

  • IOC: MRI followed by 3 dimension USG
  • Gold Standard - Laparoscopy

questions.text: All are components of quadruple marker except?
questions.solution: Reference: William's Obstetrics, 26th edition, chapter 16, page no. 308

choices.text: Manual removal of placenta under GA

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida patient was admitted to the labor room with labor pain. During the second stage of labor she was exhausted so the obstetrician performed forceps delivery. Immediately after delivery she started bleeding with tachycardia and hypotension. Placenta did not deliver and there was shortening of umbilical cord. Obstetrician attempted manual removal of the placenta but could not reach the placental attachment. What would be the best step in management of this patient after initial resuscitation?
questions.solution:
Rupture following manipulative or instrumental delivery:

Sudden deterioration of the general condition of the patient with varying amounts of vaginal bleeding following manipulative or instrumental delivery raises the suspicion. Exploration of the uterus to feel the rent confirms the diagnosis. Not infrequently, the diagnosis is not revealed until after varying intervals following development of shock or broad ligament hematoma or peritonitis. Shortening of the cord immediately following a difficult vaginal delivery is pathognomonic of uterine rupture, the placenta being extruded out into the abdominal cavity, through the rent in the uterus.

Reference: D C Dutta's textbook of obstetrics 8th edition, chapter 29
